s.text: Almost every city in America has a publication like this, a paper that is parochial in the best possible way.
(Sidewalk, on the other hand, is engaged in a nasty legal battle with Ticketmaster, and probably won't be able to strike a similar deal.)

Before I indentured myself to Microsoft and its stock options, I worked for a publication called the Washington City Paper . The City Paper is what journalists pretentiously call an "alternative weekly" and what everyone else calls a "rag."
Like any decent local paper, it views the city as the place of man's highest achievement, of clashing ideas, power struggles, great ambitions.
It's a free paper, full of listings and reviews, that can be picked up from bookstores and restaurants on Thursday evenings, and from gutters and trash piles on Friday morning.
